para.para.body: Let \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_n be a conditionally convergent series. Then, for arbitrary L\in \RNr\union\Set{\pm\infty} , there exists a rearrangement \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_{\sigma_n} of the original series which converges to L . Moreover, the series may be rearranged so that it diverges.
Riemann’s rearrangement theorem asserts that the terms of a conditionally convergent series may be rearranged so as to alter its limit or even cause it to diverge. – See the details of this theorem.
Riemann’s Rearrangement Theorem follows by combining the following observations:
Dropping from the sequence of summands (a_n) all negative summands leaves the infinite subsequence b_0,b_1,\dots ,b_n,\dots of non-negative numbers.
Dropping from the sequence of summands (a_n) all non-positive summands leaves an infinite subsequence c_0,c_1,\dots ,c_n,\dots of negative numbers.
The sequence (a_n) converges to 0 , and so the subsequences (b_n) and (c_n) converge to 0 as well.
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}b_n = +\infty , and \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n = -\infty .
With this information we now sketch a process which rearranges to summands in the original series so as to obtain a series which converges to L .

Case 1:
L

Let \mu_0 := \min\Set{ k\in \NNr \st b_0+\cdots +b_k > L} . Such \mu_0 exists and is unique by property c) above. For 0\leq i\leq \mu_0 , let a_{\sigma(i)}:= b_i , and set P_0:=b_0+\cdots b_{\mu_0} .

Then \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_{\sigma_n} is a rearrangement of the original series. By design, it converges to L .

Case 2:
L=+\infty . – We modify the process developed if L\in \RNr as follows.
Let \mu_0 := \min\Set{ k\in \NNr \st b_0+\cdots +b_k > 0} . Such \mu_0 exists and is unique by property c) above. For 0\leq i\leq \mu_0 , let a_{\sigma(i)}:= b_i , and set P_0:=b_0+\cdots b_{\mu_0} .

Let

u_0} .

Let \mu_1 := \min\Set{ k\geq \mu_0+1 \st N_0+b_{\mu_0+1} +\cdots + b_{k} } > 1 . For \mu_0+1 \leq i\leq \mu_1 , let a_{\sigma(\nu_0 + 1 + i)} := b_i , and set P_1:= N_0 + b_{\mu_0+1}+ \cdots + b_{\mu_1} .

Continue inductively: if the for r\geq 0
\mu_r , \nu_r , P_r > r , and N_r < r have been obtained, then ...

Let \mu_{r+1} := \min\Set{ k\geq \mu_r+1 \st N_r+b_{\mu_{r}+1} +\cdots + b_{\mu_r+k} } > r+1 . For \mu_r+1 \leq i\leq \mu_{r+1} , let a_{\sigma(\nu_r+1+i)} := b_i , and set P_{r+1}:= N_r + b_{\mu_r+1}+ \cdots + b_{\mu_{r+1}} .
Then \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} a_{\sigma_n} is a rearrangement of the original series. By design, it converges to +\infty .

Case 3:
L=-\infty . – One way to see this is to modify the process developed if L=+\infty . Alternatively, apply case 2 to \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}-a_n so as to obtain a rearrangement with \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}-a_{\sigma(n)} = +\infty . It follows that \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}a_{\sigma(n)} = -\infty .

u_0} .
